hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Malik ibn Ismail: He narrated to us Israel, from Abu Ishaq, from Habashi ibn Jinadah, who said: The Prophet ﷺ said: "Whoever asks from (others) without being in poverty, then he is eating from fire (coals)". And Malik said: He narrated to us Sharik. (The collector asked): Where did you hear this from Habashi? He said: He stopped by our gathering and narrated to it. In its chain there is defect.

narrators.name: Malik ibn Ismail
narrators.full_name: Malik ibn Ismail ibn Abd al-Rahman al-Azdi

narrators.name: Israel
narrators.full_name: Israel ibn Yunus ibn Abi Ishaq al-Azdi

narrators.name: Abu Ishaq
narrators.full_name: Amr ibn Abd Allah al-Hamdani al-Kufi

narrators.name: Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
narrators.full_name: Muhammad ibn Abdullah ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim

chainIssues: Israel uses 'an (عن) which is indirect transmission - potential disconnection
Abu Ishaq uses 'an (عن) - noted that Abu Ishaq had incidents of tadlis according to some scholars but is generally considered reliable
Habashi ibn Jinadah is the critical weak point - completely unknown in reliability (majhul al-hal), narrated by only one or few narrators
The source itself notes 'في إسناده نظر' (there is defect in this chain)
The editorial note records that when questioned about where Abu Ishaq heard from Habashi, he said Habashi simply stopped by their gathering and narrated - this indicates uncertain direct hearing

narrators.name: Malik ibn Ismail

chainIssues: This chain appears incomplete - the narrator after Sharik is not mentioned
Malik provides an alternative chain but it breaks off abruptly

potential_issues.issue: Habashi ibn Jinadah is majhul al-hal (unknown in reliability)
potential_issues.impact: This is a critical weakness - he is either narrated from by very few or the scholars have no information about his reliability

potential_issues.issue: Israel ibn Yunus uses 'an (عن) with indirect transmission
potential_issues.impact: Creates ambiguity about direct hearing, though Israel is generally considered acceptable (Saduq Yukhtī)
While Abu Ishaq is generally reliable (Thiqah), the 'an transmission combined with the editorial note about the chain defect raises concerns

potential_issues.issue: Source explicitly notes 'في إسناده نظر' (defect in chain)
potential_issues.impact: The original source flags this hadith as problematic

potential_issues.issue: Abu Ishaq's connection to Habashi is questionable
potential_issues.impact: When asked where he heard from Habashi, Abu Ishaq said he 'stopped by our gathering' - indicating uncertain/opportunistic hearing rather than proper teacher-student transmission

potential_issues.issue: Malik ibn Ismail is saduq sayyi' al-hifz (poor in memory)
potential_issues.impact: First narrator in the chain has documented memory issues

potential_issues.issue: Second chain via Sharik is incomplete
potential_issues.impact: Chain breaks off after Sharik with no continuation recorded

hadiths.english_translation: A Basran shaykh - narrated from him: Abu Shaykh. Ali ibn Nasr said: Haywan is Abu Shaykh, from his brother Himam, the hadith scholars call him by that (name), but as for our scholars, they do not know (him) except as Jaman, and there are his brother's descendants here but we know him only as Jaman. Yahya ibn Kathir said: (He is) ibn Dirham, from Ali ibn Mubarak Jaman with lightening (of the damma)
